title: Quarto Workshop
text:
1 Introduction to Quarto
This is a workshop on Quarto that will cover the basics of Quarto, including how to create a new Quarto project, how to write Quarto documents, and how to render Quarto documents.

title: 2  Introduction to Quarto
text:
By Christopher C. Smith
Slides: https://github.com/chriscarrollsmith/quarto-workshop

title: 3  Why Quarto? (part 1)
text:
Single source of truth: With Quarto, you can write a plain text (markdown) file that renders to many formats, including Word, PDF, or full HTML websites.
Reproducible: A researcher can write R and Python code directly in the source files, and the full analysis pipeline will automatically run and regenerate plots and tables on every render.

title: 4  Why Quarto? (part 2)
text:
Traceable: Since markdown is super lightweight, you can check your code, results, and analysis into version control to see who made what changes and when (for instance for proving research provenance or tracing scientific misconduct).
AI-friendly: Unlike Jupyter Notebooks, Quarto is really easy to edit with AI-powered tools (like Cursor, Cline, and Claude Code) because the source files are plain text.

title: 5  Skip the setup
text:
GitHub


To skip all the installation steps for this workshop, use a GitHub Codespace:

1. Go to the repo: https://github.com/chriscarrollsmith/quarto-workshop.
2. Click the green “Code” button.
3. Select the “Codespaces” tab, then “Create codespace on main”.

GitHub will start a cloud dev environment with Quarto, Python, R, and LaTeX pre-configured. It might take a few minutes to start, because it’s downloading and building all the dependencies from scratch.

title: 12  Editor modes
text:
There are two editor modes for working with .qmd (Quarto Markdown) files in VSCode:

Source mode: This is the default mode. It lets you edit the document as a plain text file with mostly standard markdown syntax.
Visual editor mode: This mode lets you edit the document using a visual editor that provides a “what you see is what you get” interface for the document.

To switch modes, right-click in the document or search “Quarto: Edit” in the command palette (“View > Command Palette” or ctrl + shift + P).
If editing with AI, you should use source mode.

title: 13  Quarto YAML headers

14 Quarto YAML headers
Most Quarto documents start with a YAML header that controls metadata and output.

Available options documented here: https://quarto.org/docs/reference/formats/opml.html
The Quarto Extension for VSCode will give you tool tips and autocomplete for the YAML header.

title: 15  Plotting with R
text:
Quarto supports executable R code blocks. The output is rendered alongside the code.

# Plot the 'cars' dataset
plot(cars, main = "Stopping Distance vs Speed", 
     xlab = "Speed (mph)", ylab = "Distance (ft)", 
     col = "blue", pch = 19)

title: 16  Plotting with Python
text:
You can also use Python for plotting. Quarto uses the Jupyter engine to execute Python code.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Ensure matplotlib and numpy are installed in your environment
# e.g., pip install matplotlib numpy

# Generate data
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x)

# Create plot
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
plt.plot(x, y, label='sin(x)', color='red')
plt.title('Simple Sine Wave')
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('y')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

title: 17  Execution Options
text:
Control code execution and display with cell options (lines starting with #|).
The main use case for code that’s evaluated but not echoed is to perform setup steps, as state is persisted across code blocks.

# Access variable from previous block
from IPython.display import Markdown

rows = [f"| `{k}` | {v} |" for k, v in options.items()]
table = "| Option | Description |\n|---|---|\n" + "\n".join(rows)

Markdown(table)




Option
Description




eval
Evaluate the code chunk (true/false).


echo
Include source code in output (true/false/fenced).


output
Include results in output (true/false/asis).


warning
Include warnings in output (true/false).

text:

title: 20  Converting to a Book
text:
To render all files as a book, create a _quarto.yml file:
project:
  type: book

book:
  title: "Quarto Workshop"
  author: "Chris"
  chapters:
    - 01.qmd
    - 02.qmd
    - 03.qmd
    # ... list all files in desired order

bibliography: references.bib

format:
  html:
    theme: cosmo
Then render the book:
quarto render
